results.title: The Rumble in the jungle
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. At 33 years of age, Ali is at a crossroads. From being unbeatable to losing two straight bouts - first with Joe Frazier, who took the title, and then with Ken Norton who left Muhammad Ali badly beaten and with a broken jaw. His struggle to regain the title from Joe Frazier becomes an obsession but his critics grow ever more doubtful. On top of that, Ali receives the news that a new player is in town: Joe Frazier is brutally beaten by newcomer, George Foreman, the hardest hitting boxer of all time. Promoter Don King persuades Ali to fight Forman in Zaire for 5 million dollars. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment

results.title: The Road back
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode begins in 1970. Ali is the most loved and the most despised athlete in the world. He is in his prime, the fasted heavyweight boxer in the world. He is at a time when all other great and powerful boxers don’t even come close. He has never lost a fight. All but two of his long list of bouts were by knockout - until he fights Joe Frazier. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: Exile
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode starts in March, 1967, and critics are starting to call Ali one of the greatest boxers of all time. As his fame grows, so does his extraordinary glib manner culminating in his famous quote: “I aint got no quarrel with the Viet Cong.” Ali becomes a conscientious objector and from avoiding the draft because of his religious beliefs, he is stripped of his title and coined an outlaw in the Spring of ‘67. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: The Youngest heavyweight champion
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. In this episode Cassius Clay wins the title from Sonny Liston and becomes the youngest heavyweight champion in the world, something that surprised even his most confident supporters - an amazing and occurrent theme throughout his career. It is 1965 and U.S. conflicts within and without swell the rest of the globe. Clay becomes a surprising player in news, religion, politics and culture and in two years “Cassius Clay” will no longer exist. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: The Beginning: Olympic gold
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Time-Warner and Turner Home Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This first episode documents Cassius Clay’s first transverse into non-professional boxing from his beginnings to Olympic success. It also takes into account his introduction to Islam and the effect this would have in his later life. This is the beginning chapter into the life of the greatest champion in the history of boxing. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: Highlands of New Guinea
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Social and economic changes in the Western Highlands of Papua New Guinea as demonstrated in the construction of an airstrip at Lake Kopiagu and the first Mount Hagen Show. Credits include Stanley Hawes, Frank Bagnall, Maslyn William, Shan Benson, Dennis Hill and Robert Gibbs.

results.title: Water: our problem
results.creator_credit: Joe Scully, John Martin-Jones, Lee Robinson, Maslyn Williams and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Illustrates our dependence on water and our inability to exist without it. Tells why Australia has water shortages and what is being done to irrigate the great inland tracts from mountainous regions of heavy snowfall and abundant rains. Australia has the largest artesian basin in the world, from which thousands of square miles have been made productive. Scientific progress has been made in the fields of rainmaking by chemical cloud dusting, and desalination of sea water.

results.title: Sir John Monash
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, State Electricity Commission of Victoria and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Reviews the life and work of the Australian scholar, lawyer, soldier and engineer, Sir John Monash. Shows his career as an engineer; a commander of troops in World War I; and his work as a Commissioner of the State Electricity Commission during the development of Yallourn. Edited by Jennie Blackwood; photographed by Adrian Bodington; sound by Alan Allen; introduction by John West.

Episode of Series “Australia today”.
